label: H3

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: properly only if the management performs its HR function satisfactorily.

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: the short , medium & long run.

label: BODY

text: importance of HRM has increased because of the shortage of really
label: BODY

text: managerial talent in the country.

text: 2. Importance for the employees
label: H3

label: BODY

text: financial & non-financial incentives.

label: BODY

text: contribute their maximum to the achievement of the organisational objectives.

text:  Effective management of HR promotes team wok & team spirit among
label: BODY

text: employees.

text: OBJECTIVES OF HRM
label: H2

label: H3

text:  To manage human resources in an ethical & socially responsible
label: BODY

text: manner.
label: BODY

text:  To ensure compliance with legal & ethical standards.
label: BODY

text:  To minimise the negative impact of societal demands upon the
label: BODY

text: organisation.
label: BODY

label: H3

text:  HR department, like any other department in an organisation, should
label: BODY

text: focus on achieving the goals of the organisation first. If it does not meet
label: BODY

text: this purpose, the HR department cannot exist in the long run.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: organisational effectiveness.

label: BODY

text: more or less sophisticated to suit the organisation’s demands.
label: BODY

text:  The department’s level of service must be tailored to fit the organisation
label: BODY

text: it serves.
label: BODY

text:  HRM  should employ the skills & abilities of the workforce efficiently.
label: BODY

text: It should aim at making the people’s strength more productive &
label: BODY

text: beneficial to the organisation.
label: BODY

text:  HRM should aim at providing the organisation with well trained & well
label: BODY

text: motivated employees.
label: BODY

text: 4) Personnel Objectives
label: H3

text:  HRM should increase employees job satisfaction to the fullest extent.
label: BODY

text:  HRM should also meet the self actualisation needs of the employees. It
label: BODY

text: organisation.

text:  HRM should develop & maintain a quality of work life. It makes
label: BODY

text: employment in the organisation a desirable, personal & social situation.
label: BODY

text: Organisational performance can never be improved without the quality
label: BODY

text: of work life.

text: FUNCTIONS OF HRM( 15 marks 2017 & 2018)
label: H2

text: 1. MANAGERIAL FUNCTION
label: H3

text: Managerial function includes
label: BODY

text: a) Planning:-
label: H3

text: It is pre-determined course of action. Planning pertain to formulating
label: BODY

text: strategies of personnel programmes & changes in advance that will
label: BODY

text: contribute to the organisational goals.
label: BODY

text: In other words it involves planning of HR, requirements, selection, training
label: BODY

text: etc.
label: BODY

text: b) Organising:- an organisation is a means to an end. It is essential to carry
label: H3

text: out the determined course of action. Acc. to J.C Massie, an organisation is a
label: BODY

text: structure & a process by which a co-operative group of human beings
label: BODY

text: allocates its task among its members, identifies relationship & integrates its
label: BODY

text: activities towards a common objective.
label: BODY

text: c) Directing:- activating employees at different level & making them
label: H3

text: contribute maximum to the organisation is possible through proper direction
label: BODY

text: & motivation. Taping the maximum potentialities of the employees is
label: BODY

text: possible through motivation  & command.
label: BODY

text: d) Controlling:- after  planning, organizing, & directing the actual
label: H3

text: performance of employees is checked, verified & compared with the plans.
label: BODY

text: It the actual performance is found deviated from the plan, control measures
label: BODY

text: are required to be taken.
label: BODY

text: ii) OPERATIVE FUNCTIONS
label: H3

text: the operative functions of HRM are related to specific activities like
label: BODY

text: 1) Employment:-
label: H3

text: It is concerned with securing & employing the people possessing the required
label: BODY

text: kind & level of human resources necessary to achieve the organisational
label: BODY

text: objectives. It includes
label: BODY

text: i) Job Analysis:- it is the process of study & collection of information
label: BODY

text: relating to the Role & Responsibilities of a specific job.
label: BODY

text: ii) HR Planning:- it is a process for determination & assuring that the
label: BODY

text: organisation will have an adequate number of qualified persons,
label: BODY

text: available at proper times, performing jobs, which would meet the needs
label: BODY

text: of the organisation & which would provide satisfaction for the
label: BODY

text: individuals involved.
label: BODY

text: EVOLUTION OF HRM ( 5 marks )
label: H2

text: The evolution of the concept of Human Resource Management is presented below
label: BODY

text:  Period before industrial revolution – The society was primarily an
label: BODY

text: agriculture economy with limited production. Number of specialized crafts was
label: BODY

text: limited and was usually carried out within a village or community with
label: BODY

text: apprentices assisting the master craftsmen. Communication channel were
label: BODY

text: limited.
label: BODY

text:  Period of industrial revolution (1750 to 1850) – Industrial revolution marked
label: BODY

text: the conversion of economy from agriculture based to industry based.
label: BODY

text: Modernization and increased means if communication gave way to industrial
label: BODY

text: setup. A department was set up to look into workers wages, welfare and other
label: BODY

text: related issues. This led to emergence of personnel management with the major
label: BODY

text: task as
label: BODY

text: – Worker’s wages and salaries
label: BODY

text: – Worker’s record maintenance

text: – Worker’s housing facilities and health care
label: BODY

text: An important event in industrial revolution was growth of Labour Union (1790) –
label: BODY

text: The works working in the industries or factories were subjected to long working hours
label: BODY

text: and very less wages. With growing unrest , workers across  the world started protest
label: BODY

text: and this led to the establishment of Labour unions. To deal with labour issues at one
label: BODY

text: end and management at the other Personnel Management department had to
label: BODY

text: be  capable of politics and diplomacy , thus the industrial relation department
label: BODY

text: emerged.
label: BODY

text:  Post  Industrial revolution – The term Human resource Management saw a
label: BODY

text: major evolution after 1850. Various studies were released and many
label: BODY

text: experiments were conducted during this period which gave HRM altogether a
label: BODY

text: new meaning and importance.
label: BODY

text: A brief overview of major theories release during this period is presented below
label: BODY

text:  Frederick W. Taylor gave principles of scientific management (1857 o 1911) led to
label: BODY

text: the evolution of scientific human resource management approach which was
label: BODY

text: involved in
label: BODY

text: – Worker’s training
label: BODY

text: – Maintaining wage uniformity
label: BODY

text: – Focus on attaining better productivity.
label: BODY

text: Hawthorne studies, conducted by Elton Mayo & Fritz Roethlisberger (1927 to 1940).
label: BODY

text: – Observations and findings of Hawthrone experiment shifted the focus of Human
label: BODY

text: resource from increasing worker’s productivity to increasing worker’s efficiency
label: BODY

text: through greater work satisfaction.
label: BODY

text: Douglas McGregor Theory X and Theory Y (1960) and Abraham Maslow’s
label: BODY

text: Hierarchy of needs ( 1954) – These studies and observations led to the transition
label: BODY

text: from the administrative and passive Personnel Management approach to a more
label: BODY

text: dynamic Human Resource Management approach which considered workers as a
label: BODY

text: valuable resource.
label: BODY

text: As a result of these principles and studies, Human resource management became
label: BODY

text: increasingly line management function , linked to core business operations. Some of
label: BODY

text: the major activities of HR department are listed as-
label: BODY

text: 1. Recruitment and selection of skilled workforce.
label: BODY

text: 2. Motivation and employee benefits
label: BODY

text: 3. Training and development of workforce
label: BODY

text: 4. Performance related salaries and appraisals.
